Paper hats for chorus in number Joan of Arc.
Tray and plates or small dishes for Connie.
Engagement book for Connie with pencil
Book for Blair - a street organ off L.
Visiting cards for Blair - Menus on tables.
A mongrel dog on a rope for Sally off stage L.
A tray with celery and prop Grisini for Connie
A Waiter from E.3 with tray filled with silver dishes
Another clears Grisini-table R. front- (Newspaper for Otis) Tap-bell on some of tables - (a hip flask for Otis)- a lemon for Otis- a whisk broom for Connie-(a hip flask for Connie)
Note - the phone can be fastened to a tree A dish pail for Sally to wash dishes in
Custard, ornamented with a large bow ribbon carried by Rosie
A tray of liquors and a tray with coffee, carried by two flunkeys - a flunkey with a cart and liquors.

div.stage: SCENE: The Elm Alley Inn. A garden restaurant of the Bohemian variety. A large elm tree is growing in the yard and this gives the restaurant its name. There is a balcony built around this tree and stops going up to it.
There are a number of little tables in the yard and on a covered terrace at the back that opens on the garden through glass doors, there are more tables.

To the right is the rear facade of the house; to the left a high wall covered with lattice. There is a doorway is this wall that opens into the alley. There is lattice work over the other walls, too, and on either side of the terrace frescoed panels with figure subjects.

OPENING: At rise there are occupants at most of the tables. The Inn of Elm Tree Alley is apparently a favorite resort of couples whose interest in each other is so great that they prefer to be in a place where they won't be subject of remark. Hence the popularity of this little Bohemian resort. There is a party of four at one table and seated alone at another table is ROSIE with her back turned reading a newspaper. She is waiting for Otis.
The proprieter and the WAITER come in with the checks. Business of paying checks.

lg.l: The night time, when the lights are bright
It's the night time when we feel just right.
Makes a chappie feel so happy
We're so snappy, we're full of fight.
There's something doing.
It's the night walk that we love to prowl
It's the night hawk, that's the wise old owl
Bet your life we have to fall
When the lark is singing gaily
And the sun is overhead
While the world is working daily
We love to lie in bed.
Honest toil may be a treasure
But it has no charm for us.
The night was made - of leisure
Let others fume and fuss
For simple rustic pleasure
We do not care a straw.
We think it's great to stay out late at night
And skate around with Maud and Kate.
We love the boys and all the noise
And lively plays and cabarets.

div.stage: (For finish of number TWO DANCERS enter... dance with JIM...all exit)
(OTIS breezes in carrying hat, coat and big rubber tire. A pretty hatcheck GIRL follows him)

sp.speaker: Hatcheck Girl
sp.p: Check your hat and coat, sir?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Never mind the hat and coat - take my spare tire.
sp.stage: (He rolls it at her. GIRL takes it and exits)
sp.p: I'm too smart for this New York. Now I'm going to roast this town when I get back to Squantanville.
Elmer - Elmer - come back here!
I get some bottles there.
Ah, glamourpuss, there you are....hello, Rosie.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: I thought you said you'd meet me here at half past seven.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Sorry, honeybun, but I had to see a man about that mink coat I promised you.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Really, Otis? When do I get it?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: That's up to Peter and Maizie.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Are they the furriers?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: No. Peter and Maizie are minks - they're a pair of live, lovely, pedigreed minks. I just bought 'em for you.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You said you wanted a mink coat, didn't you? Why pay a thousand dollars when you can grow your own.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Grow my own. You know how many minks it takes to make a coat.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You'll be surprised how easy it'll be. Peter and Maizie are just crazy about each other. What a cutey-pie! I could set you right up! You're going to be my little passion flower and I'm going to be your little pay envelope.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Little pay is right.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: That has all the ear marks of a nasty crack. What about tying on the feed bag? Now go right ahead and order what you like - You know me, big hearted Otis. You want to be careful what you're ordering -- they say that this place is noted for its ptomaine-poisoning.
sp.stage: (Music plays off stage R.piano and violin)
sp.p: Ah, they've got music here. What do you say now? Shall we trip a measure in the dance while we're waiting for the waiter?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: O.K. Jitterbug. But if you step on my feet just once, I'll tear you limb from limb.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: What are you saying? Why I was known as the dancing dervish of Squantanville.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Maybe you go big in those huskin' bees, in the barn, but in New York.....

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: There you go --- "New York" again --- I tell you this burg is slow. We've got steps up home you folks have never heard of. How about the frog dip? Or the Malary shiver. Or the Jelly roll?

sp.speaker: Otis and Girls
sp.stage: (OTIS sings to ROSIE and dances with her first)

lg.l: In Squantanville, Maine
We've Jazz on the brain,
We turn on the family victrols,
On dancing we're keen
And I'm the champeen
I dance till I loosen each molar
I tremble and shrill to the core,
Like a jelly that's dropped on the floor.
On with the Dance,
On with the Dance,
Let me twirl in the whirl tonight,
I'll cling to some beautiful Vamp,
As close as the gum to a stamp.
I'll slither and slip,
I'll hug and I'll grip
I must have a night of romance;
To some Cutey in blue
Oh Boy what I'll do
At the dance; on with the dance.
I'll show them a step
All ginger and pep,
I'm one of the likeliest starters;
I'll shimmy and shake,
And I'll twist like a snake,
Till I wriggle clean out of my garters.
I'll find me a maiden so frail,
I'll grab her and prove I'm a whale.
On with the dance,
On with the dance,
Let me twirl in the whirl tonight,
With some sweetie I'll roam,
We'll both miss our last Trolley home.
I'll cuddle and squeeze
And sag at the knees;
I must have a night of romance;
If your wife I should see
Don't trust her with me,
At the dance; on with the dance.

div.stage: (During dance with Vamp, ROSIE enters with MAN R.2.E.)

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Now you see the evils of dancing.
Pardon me. I thought you had a shirt on.

div.stage: (ROSIE and MAN dance. OTIS takes her away from him, they dance and exit R.1.E. VAMP and MAN exit L. through gate)
(After number "ON WITH THE DANCE" ALL exit)
(Music S. in to the entrance music for the SETTLEMENT GIRLS who enter through gate followed by MRS. TEN BROCK)
(There are SIX GIRLS and SALLY. They are all in very cheap clothes - torn, patched. SALLY is in the middle of the line. POPS enters from restaurant.)

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Good evening.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Good evening. I am Mrs. Ten Brock - I have been doing settlement work in the neighborhood. You wrote to our Matron, saying you wanted a young girl.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Yes - to wash dishes.

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Wash dishes!

div.stage: (ALL the GIRLS tip-toe to gate L. and try to crowd out. MRS. TEN BROCK calls to them)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Girls! Girls!

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Come back here. Do behave and please turn out your toes.

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Yes, ma'am!

div.stage: (They form an oblique line at L.C. of stage)

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I used to have the Waiters do it, but I've got a fellow now, that has a grudge against dishes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: I see. Now these are all lovely girls. This is Miss Schuyler - Miss Bryan, Miss Audubon, and the dark girl is Miss Plaza.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: My, my what wonderful names they have. Will ladies that belong to such fine families, really work for me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: They are all foundlings. They were named from the telephone districts in which they were found. The one on the end is Miss Green.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Green?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: She was really named Bowling Green, but it seemed rather long.
They all have their good points.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: There's only one point that interests me in a dish-washer - have they got non-skid hands.
sp.stage: (Stops SALLY and the GIRLS exit R.2.E.)
sp.p: I like this one. Would you like the job, young lady?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I would not!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Why Sally!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Have you ever washed dishes?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Well, I can't say I have.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I thought not. What else will I have to do?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Oh, just clean out the place, run errands - and so on --

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Sew on what - buttons?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: No, no! So on, means anything.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Take me away, Mrs. Ten Brock. I don't want to stay in a place, where they ask me to do anything.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Don't be silly, Sally, Mr. Shendoff is a very nice man.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Have you seen his references?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: You must be more respectful to your employer.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Now, do you think you could mop up this floor?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Borck
sp.p: No what, Sally --

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: No - mop.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I'll give you the mop -- Do you want the job?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I certainly don't -- but I guess I'll have to take it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Certainly, Ma'am.

div.stage: (Exit MRS. TEN BROCK and POPS R.U.E.)

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Other girls get interesting jobs - look at Joan Crawford, look at Merle Oberon.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Sally's a dish-washer -- Sally's a dish-washer.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Gee, if there's one job I hate, it's bathing dishes.

sp.speaker: 3rd Girl
sp.p: Maybe you'll be a cashier some day.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I don't want to be any old cashier -- I want to be famous.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl
sp.p: Gee, you're always harping on being famous, you make me tired.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: What's eaten you?

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl
sp.p: You've got a long way to go girlie.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: That's all right, but I'll get there. Other girls have done it. Why Joan of Arc didn't start any higher up than I am.

lg.l: Joan of Arc was on her own,
When she was quite a child;
They thought her head was made of bone,
But she just calmly smiled.
They had their troubles at the time,
And everybody know it;
When Kings and Dukes kept making flukes,
She said, "Here let me do it."
I wish I could be like Joan of Arc,
You bet that girl was through;
They joshed her when she started,
But she never got downhearted
And it shows what a kid can do.
She wrote her name on the nation's roll of fame,
And it gained her great renown;
Though her Pa and Ma poor Fishes,
Tried to keep her washing dishes;
But you can't keep a good girl down.
She had no stairs to wash
With soap suds and a pail;
She just cut out domestic bosh,
And bought a suit of Mail.
They handed her the icy mitt
But still she was unshaken,
She showed the foe some tricks - yes ho
And soon brought home bacon.
I wish I could be like Joan of Arc,
She was "it" right from the start;
When the hired girl was busy
Well it used to make her dizzy,
So she said "Here's where we part,"
She loved to fight and when foe-men came in
She would hand them Dempsey punches,
Where they used to keep their lunches;
For you can't keep a good girl down.

div.stage: ("CONNIE" enters. He is attired as waiter - carries a tray. As he enters he stumbles and takes running fall all across stage. WAITER gather up dishes - then exit)
(POPS enters behind him just as he recovers himself and steadies his gait down to a trot. He doesn't see Pops but begins to search about floor. POPS comes over and stands beside him)

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: What are you looking for? What's all the commotion.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I had a tip on the tray.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: A dime.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: A what?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: A dime. I was looking for it. Maybe it's under your feet?
sp.stage: (POPS stands on one leg while CONNIE searches floor)
sp.p: No, the other foot?
sp.stage: (POPS steps on Connie's feet. Bus. CONNIE with foot falling)
sp.p: Now you've done it. There it goes!
Now how am I going through life with a thing like that - there it goes.
I'll have to use some Sloan's liniment.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Is that good?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Certainly it's good. Mix a little orange juice with it -- kills the taste - there it goes.
As though I hadn't had troubles enough.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I am very sorry, your Highness.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Don't salute, don't want people to know that the Duke of Checkergovinia, is a waiter in a third class restaurant.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: A third class restaurant?
What do you mean, sir --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'm wrong - I admit it.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I'm glad you do.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: It's not third class. It's a fourth class.
My position and everything's gone from me.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Haven't I given you another position?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'm speaking about my social position.
sp.stage: (Snatches up a plate and smashes it)
sp.p: There -- I always feel better when I smash something.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I think I'd feel better if I smashed something.
Your Highness!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Don't salute. Are you or are you not a loyal supporter of the ducal family of Pzchekagovinia?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Haven't I proved my loyalty? After you were kicked out and came to New York penniless and friendless, didn't I take you in and treat you as one of the family?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Yes -- that's what I'm complaining of. I asked you - are you - are you not a loyal supporter?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Yes, I am!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Give me next Thursday night off!

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I knew it would be something like that! Whenever you start in about my loyalty I always feels a touch coming. I fire a good waiter and engage you out of loyalty and you do nothing but ask me for days off.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: All right. If I am ever restored I shall give you the order of the cross of Anastasia -- that I have promised -- but you'll never get the order of the golden caterpillar --

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Oh please--your Highness!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Don't salute! When do I get off?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: But where do I get off? I've only got three other waiters--

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: When do I get off?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Next Thursday.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You may kiss our hand.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Pardon me. My thoughts had strayed back to summer days in dear old Checkergovinia.
I shall now be able to accept Mr. Farquar's invitation to attend the ball, given in my honor.

div.stage: (Xes to table L. takes tray filled with dishes)

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Have none of your friends found out how it is you make your living?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Of course not. I tell them all I must withold my address for political reasons - owing to the activity of the revolutionists I am living incog--

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: In what? Where is that? That incog--

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: It's not a place, it's --
When I say I'm living incog, I mean - I'm living incognito.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Oh, that's so simple!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I know you are. Now you had better come and help me wash the dishes.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Now, I'm busy.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You had better come and help me wash the dishes.
You don't have to help me wash the dishes.

div.stage: (POPS raving, exits R.U.E. Enter BLAIR. BLAIR comes in reading a book)

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Good evening.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Good evening. Table for one.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: No, for eight.
Waiter, here's a dollar. Won't you please give it to that organ grinder and ask him to go away?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Certainly, sir.
sp.stage: (Pockets dollar. Throws plate, comes back rubbing his hands)
sp.p: All attended to, sir.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Let me see. I wrote out the menu for supper. Where did I put it?
Here it is.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Two young children -- a touch of arsenic -- a --

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Oh, excuse me. There are all chapter headings in my novel. The menu is on the other side.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Celery, olives. Ox tail soup - you're going away back. I must be careful with that. If I should give it to the cook wrongside up, there'd be trouble. Imagine a touch of arsenic. Did I understand you to say you were an author?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Yes, I write books.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Well, sir -- Do you mind paying for this in advance?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: In advance?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: It is a rule of the house---artists and writers must pay in advance.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Here is my card--I think the proprietor knows me.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: He knows all of you, that's why he made this rule.
Mr. Blair Farquar--Oh, I beg pardon. You are a relative of the great financier--Richard Farquar, I believe?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: He is my father.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Ah yes! What a coincidence - your father -

Sit down, it's all right. I beg your pardon - my mistake - your error. Tell me -- are you likely to attend the party that Mr. Farquar is giving in honor of his Highness the Grand Duke of Pzchekagovinia?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Not if I can help it.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: I hear the Duke is an absolute ninny.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Mah! Ha! Ha!

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: My friend met him and as Jim puts it, a brain specialist couldn't make peanut money working on him.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Is that so? You want me to fix this supper for you good?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Wait and see.

div.stage: (There is a sound of commotion in the alley. VOICES and whoops, cat calls, SALLY runs across stage entering from right and shooting off through gate left)

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: What was that that shot across?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That was the new dishwasher---escaping.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Couldn't stand washing dishes any longer--Really I don't wonder. Poor kid what an awful way to have to make your living!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: What about me?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Ha ha yourself! Why give her all the sympathy. How about me. She's got gold in her teeth. Gold! I don't even get meat in mine.

div.stage: (Quarrel off stage L. over dog. SALLY enters. CONNIE exits into restaurant)

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Don't you dare!

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Say kid, where do you get that stuff!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.stage: (Backs through gate, leading a mongrel dog, protectively. He has a but of rope tied around his neck)**
sp.p: If there's any of youse kids that are sick of livin' -- you just touch my dawg -- again -- see?

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Next time I'll tie cane to his ears.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Is that your dog?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Yes. He followed me over here and the kids get hold of him and tied a tomato can to his tail. Shake hands with the gentleman Custard.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: He's clever, isn't he?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: You bet he is. Knows more than most men, doesn't he?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Seems to.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: And he minds better too. There -- now go on home.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: You believe in the motto "The more I see of men the more I think of dogs?"

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh men are all right I guess if you're all dolled up and look pretty.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Nonsense, I'm a man and fine clothes don't make any difference to me.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Sure; that's what they all say. But you walk up behind one of 'em and make a noise like rustlin' silk an' watch how quick he'll turn around. I've tried it.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Have you?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I need to sew sandpaper on the knees of my stockings. The affect was great but of course as soon as they looked at me it was cold.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: What do you do here - wash dishes?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Say, is it beginning to show on me? I've only had the job about fifteen minutes and the first person that sees me spots me for a dish washer.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: No, I didn't. The waiter told me.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh-h! I feel better. I thought I had dishpan hands.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: How do you like washing dishes?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Are you trying to be funny? Whoever heard of anyone that liked washing dishes?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Suppose I could find you a job you liked better.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: If you would find me any job I didn't like better you'd be a wonder!

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Well, I'll see what I can do!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh...
Will you? ... Say, you're like the man I used to read about in the story books. I didn't think there was a man like that in real life.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Are you fond of books?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I love 'em. They help you to get away from your own life.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: I'm mighty glad to find someone who thinks books really useful. You see, I write stories....

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Do you now? I wonder if you wrote my favorite about the girl the villain ties to a railroad track because she spurns his vile love? Did you write that one?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: No, that isn't one of mine.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Too bad. The hero of that one seemed a lot like you -- only of course he wouldn't have gone around in the evenin' without a full dress-suit.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: What's your name?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Sally. What's yours?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Blair.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Blair--that's a funny name. Which end do you use it?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: It's my first name. Blair Farquar.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Blair Farquar. Pleased to meet you, Mr. Blair Farquar.

div.stage: (Holds out hand then wipes hand on apron)

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: How do you do?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh, I'm pretty good.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: We're going to be friends, you and I.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Are we?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Don't you want to be? I do. I'm rather lonely sort of fellow and I like you.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Do you---really?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: And I'm going to help you if you'll let me.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: It's awful good of you! I thought I was playing in hard luck when they picked me out to wash dishes.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Things are bound to look up. There's a bright side to everything.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Even to dishpans!

lg.l: Please don't be offended if I preach to you a while.
Tears are out of place in eyes that were meant to smile.
There's a way to make your very biggest troubles small -
Here's the happy secret of it all.
I know my love will help to make you
Look for the silver lining
Whenever a cloud appears in the blue
Remember somewhere the sun is shining
And so the bright thing to do, is make it shine for you,
A heart full of joy and gladness
Can always banish sadness and strife
So always look for the silver lining
And try to find the sunny side of life.
As I wash my dishes, I'll keep following your plan
'Till I see the brightness in every pot and pan
I am sure your point of view will ease the daily grind.
So I'll keep repeating in my mind.
Look for the silver lining
Whenever a cloud appears in the blue
Remember somewhere the sun is shining
And so the bright thing to do, is make it shine for you,
A heart full of joy and gladness
Can always banish sadness and strife
So always look for the silver lining
And try to find the sunny side of life. BOTH

div.stage: (At end of number exit BLAIR off through the alley gate. SALLY watches him off)

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Hello, so you came back?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I thought you were running away.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I was thinkin' about it--but now I've changed my mind.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Just since you met me?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: No, I'm sorry, but you hadn't anything to do with it.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That settles that. Hold that.
sp.stage: (Goes to table R. arranges chairs, SALLY eats celery)
sp.p: Who were you waving to when I came in?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: None of your business.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I didn't get the name.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I said none of your business.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Sounds like Russian descent.
Hey, what are you doing? Give me that.
sp.stage: (Takes celery from Sally puts it back in jar)
sp.p: Look at that--you've got it all out of shape. You've no right to steal the celery.
You're a bad girl, and I don't like bad girls.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: What's that stuff?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That! Oh, that's grisini!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Not who...neuter gender... it...It's a kind of bread.
sp.stage: (Takes up piece, breaks it, hands it to Sally)
sp.p: You try it.
Try again.
My a woman's strength. It's very brit-til.
sp.stage: (SALLY throws broken pieces at Connie as he walks away)
sp.p: Hey! What are you doing? Here's some I just brought up... from the bakery.
The trouble is...
rather soggy tonight.
Make a good Mache.
Now it looks like niblick.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: What's your name?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Constantine - Alexandrivith Nicholas Feder Caborr -- What's your name?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Sally.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Short, isn't it? It's pretty though.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Do you like it?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Tell me, Connie --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Connie!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Tell me - why did you ever take up waiting for a living?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Well, it's a long story. I used to be in politics.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Gee, that's not much better than waiting. If I were a man I'd be something exciting.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Politics in my part of the world were exciting enough, believe me.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I want to be a singer.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: How would you like to sing here?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: In the cabaret you mean? I'd love it!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I think maybe I can arrange it for you. I'll speak to Pops, if you like.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh, will you?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: All right, Mr. Officer, I'll go along.
Don't do that...would you really like to entertain here?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: See if you'd only get me the chance, I'd make good, honest I would.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Don't worry I'll fix it with Pops. Then he won't expect me to go on in case he runs short of talent.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Does he ever do that?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: 'Deed he does. The other night Soupidina...that's the Hawaiian Princess, absolutely refused to go on and I had to go on in her place.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Cheer up. Things will be brighter some day.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Not for me. My bright future is all behind me.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Don't you believe it.

lg.l: A heart full of joy and gladness
Will always banish sadness and strife,
So always look for the silver lining,
And try to find the sunny side of life.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You wouldn't talk like that if you had been through what I have the last two years.

div.stage: (After dance, enter WAITER R.3. with tray filled with silver dishes - another WAITER clears grisini, celery, etc. Table R. front)

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well, do I waltz or do I WALTZ?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: You waltz, all right.....on'y the orchestra was playin' a rumbha, ya jerk!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You'll be telling me next I stepped on your feet.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: No. With that high knee action of yours you got me between the shin and the kneecap every time.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You used to say you could die dancing with me.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: And boy! Did I come close tonight!
Now what's this about some money you're going to make?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: That's right, dream toots. Today I clinched a deal by which I'm going to clear one thousand pieces of moo.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Yeah, I'll bet.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Cross my heart.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: What heart?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Don't change the subject. I'm going to get one thousand bucks for booking the famous and notorious Russian Madam Nockerova to appear next Thursday at a big ball given by Richard Farquar the well-to-do millionaire.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Is that so? Where did you become acquainted with this pushova-dance?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I'm not acquainted with her! I'm her agent. Her New York representative. I picked this paper up outside and the first thing I struck right here on the first page Mme. Nockerova wrecks the throne of a Grand Duke.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: A bomb-thrower?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: A bomb-thrower, nonsense. She don't have to throw bombs, with a face like that! Look at that face. No, not that one- that's Sophie Tucker. This one -
She's only a little bit of a woman, but the damage she can do!

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: I'll bet that's just press-stuff. She's probably a perfectly nice girl.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Here, what are you trying to do, ruin her reputation.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: I s'pose you think that a girl can't be on the stage and be good?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I don't say she can't but I understand it isn't strictly necessary.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Otis!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: All right, let it go! I don't know how the food is here, but the service is absolutely terrible--look over this list while I page a little service.
Garcon! Garcon!

div.stage: (CONNIE comes from R.2. stands, looks over at Otis, struts over, grabs bell, THEY struggle for it, OTIS gets it puts it back on table)

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Switch off those head lights.
Put 'em back again!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Say, what the --- That's the freshest waiter I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Welcome, Brother Elk.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Kansas City 74.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: St. Louis 49.
sp.stage: (Start toward each other to shake hands. Miss)
sp.p: Where has he gone? You want a regular dinner?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Not me. I want a footbath and some linament.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That's a la carte.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: What would you recommend, waiter?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: The food in Childs.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: I'd like some broth.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Some broth, yes, Miss.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I'd like some mutton.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Mutton broth.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: No. Mutt and Jeff.
sp.stage: (Laugh business. OTIS pushes CONNIE. He sinks to floor. Rings bell)
sp.p: Waiter! Waiter!
sp.stage: (Turning to right - then left. CONNIE dodging to right then left. Rises)
sp.p: I wish you'd light in one place.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Here I am, sir.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Oh, oh.
I wish you'd call your shots. Get me a bottle of whiskey.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: O.K. with three glasses.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Three glasses?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You'll do nothing of the kind. You'll get two glasses.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Why, aren't you drinking?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: He's the freshest waiter I ever saw!
Do you care if I smoke?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: I don't care if you burn.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Hey, waiter, I wish you'd give us a little service.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'll give you as little as I can.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well make this dinner good and snappy. Bring me a dozen clams.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Twelve clams. Will the lady be sitting with you?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Why certainly.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That's all I want to know. I don't need thirteen at the table. Twelve clams.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Rosie ain't he the character?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: May I make a suggestion?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Why not, I'm broad-minded.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: How would you like some oysters?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: No. Oysters aren't good this month.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Well, I'll give you last month's.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Chum, I hope your food is better than your jokes.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You wouldn't dare say that if I were a woman.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Shut up and take the order! Ya crumb!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Oh, a Vassar girl.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: And waiter after you have eased in here with the clams, you might bring us a couple of bowls of "soups".

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Yes sir.
sp.stage: (Starts to go then back to Otis)
sp.p: Beg pardon, sir, what was that last?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I said you might glide in here with a couple of bowls of "soups".

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Zoupe?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Zoupe!
sp.stage: (At same time turning face to Connie. THEY kiss. CONNIE pulls lemon out of pocket eats it. OTIS wipes his mouth with tablecloth, then match bus. Rings bell)
sp.p: Waiter! Waiter!
sp.stage: (CONNIE rushes madly in different directions then back to table)
sp.p: I wish you would give us a little attention, but don't be so darned affectionate.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Did you say "zoupe"?

div.stage: (THEY look at each other. BOTH put napkins over heads)

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Zoupe. Then I think I'd like some fish.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.stage: (Hits him over head with order book)**
sp.p: Now that's enough.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Rosie, I wish you wouldn't play so rough.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: I didn't do it.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I wish you wouldn't order fish.

sp.speaker: Otis and Rosie
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Isn't it fresh?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Certainly, it's fresh, we have an aquarium right on the premises.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Why if you've got an aquarium on the premises, the fish are bound to be fresh.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: And I am in charge of the aquarium.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Then you might dig in and bring us out a couple of fat ones.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I watched the little fish grow from girlhood up. Pardon me, there's your arm.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: It was hanging from your shoulder. I wish you wouldn't order fish. I've become attached to them.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I understand your feeling. You've probably become so fond of them that you've spoiled them and I hate spoiled fish. However, waiter, I can appreciate your sentiments. I can understand how anyone can really grow fond of a fish. You know Rosie, that takes me back to Squantanville. When I was a boy. Ah me, heigho, alackaday! I had a pet fish! I called her Isabelle. I was awfully fond of Isabelle, taught her a lot of tricks--even taught her to do without water.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: There's nothing strange about that. Is there, Waiter?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Oh, no.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I got Isabelle so used to going without water, I could keep her in the cage with the canary bird.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: The fish!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Yes, the fish. One evening, ah me, fateful night! How well I remember it...Isabelle was in the canary bird's cage romping around. Leaping from crag to crag like a mountain goat.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: The fish!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: The fish! Then she got upon the canary bird's perch.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: With the other fish.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Well, a perch is a fish.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You leather-head. She got on the canary bird's swing.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Oh! I give up!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Listen, she got up in the canary bird's swing...and was swinging blithely to and fro--when she lost her balance, fell into the canary bird's bath and was drowned.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: The fish?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: The fish.
sp.stage: (CONNIE attempts to strike Otis. OTIS jumps up also ROSIE. OTIS behind Rosie)
sp.p: All right Rosie. I'm right behind you.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I can sympathize with you, sir, for I too have had a great sorrow in my life.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Yes, it's showing on you.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Olga was her name.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Oh, a Russian girl?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: A hen. A barn yard person. I taught her to lay colored Easter eggs.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: The fish.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Then hen....by holding a piece of red and blue cloth in front of her eyes.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Of course - prenatal influence.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Thank you. I wish, but one day I went out to visit with my little Olga and found her dead.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Dead?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Yes. Some darn fool had hung a patchwork quilt in front of her.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: We've been listening to that darn fool and he's gone without taking our order. Come on, Rosie, let's have a dance while we're waiting.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: O.K. But remember one thing, will ya?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Your dancing with me - not at me!

div.stage: (Enter BLAIR, JIM and BOYS. General conversation as THEY enter, as tho continuing a conversation.)

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: She's just a little girl, who works here in this restaurant.

sp.speaker: Boys
sp.p: Here!

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: And you want to help her?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Yes, but I don't quite know how.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Hey, you sound in a bad way, Blair.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Don't be ridiculous. I only met here an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Yes, I know. But time has nothing to do with love.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: I guess you're right. They say when you meet the girl, something ups and says "This is it, Brother."

lg.l: There's someone that I can't forget
No matter where I go.
Though not of high degree
She's all the world to me.
A modest rose, unknown as yet
But wonderful to see
She is the darling of my heart
And I met her in the alley.
And at some future day
To her I mean to say.

div.stage: (OLD MAN and GIRL enter up Left. CONNIE from kitchen.)

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Come along my dear, this way. My, what a quaint place.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Grandpa's playing hookey. Well, Commodore, when are you going to jump? What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: I would like a nice quiet table for two.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Very sorry, but we're crowded.
Folding money. For that you can have the house.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: I would like a nice quite place where we can have a nice quiet tete-a-tete.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Too noisy, Waiter. Too noisy.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.stage: (Runs him around in a circle, ends up at same table)**
sp.p: How's this one?

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Huh?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I said, how's this one?

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Better -- much better.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I thought you'd like it.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.stage: (Takes cloth out of ear trumpet and yells down)**
sp.p: I said I thought you'd like it.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: We want crepe suzettes, waiter.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Okay Pop, one order of crepe suzettes. Coming up.

div.stage: (As he passes R. Booth line to them)

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well, how about our food. I've had nothing to eat since breakfast. I ought to be starved.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: You ought to be shot.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: All right, let it go.

div.stage: (CONNIE runs on bells on different tables ring. He puts tray on L. table, runs around to phone)

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Hello, yes, this is the Elm Tree Inn - what? Just a minute, I'll get him.
You're wanted on the phone.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I've been expecting a phone message. It's important business. Excuse me Rosie, -- where's the phone?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I've been hiding it for you.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Say, is this a game you're playing?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Beg pardon sir,
There you are, sir.
Don't do that.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well, what are you waiting for? A tip?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I wouldn't mind, sir.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Play Whirlaway, to place.
What's that you say? Madam Nockerova hasn't called? Isn't coming? This is terrible, and after all the trouble I've gone to. This will cost me a thousand dollars. What? I'll call you later.
Can you beat that for tough luck. Now my whole evening is spoiled. Rosie, this is terrible.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: That female snake! That Russian homewrecker - Hello?

You're getting on my nerves. You're a mental cripple. You ought to go around with a crutch under your chin. Can you imagine, after all the trouble I took to book that woman, now she isn't coming -- turning down the whole U.S. for a pinhead of a Duke. But why should I confide in you? Come on Rosie.

div.stage: (WAITER brings on tray with condiments and hands them to Connie)

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Ladies and Gentlemen, I wish to announce an extra cabaret attraction. Miss Sally Green.

div.stage: (SALLY does number in her ragged dress but uses a square silk to perform various dances - Dutch, Spanish, Japanese, etc. Finishes with Clog. After number all exit except Rosie, Blair, Jim and a Girl)

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Isn't she lovely? Excuse me I'm going to congratulate her.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: What do you think of Sally? Isn't she immense? Gosh that gives me a great idea. You wait here I'll be right back.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Nothing doing, I'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Waiter, waiter! Where's the waiter. The service here is awful. Waiter! Waiter!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Coming, sir, coming. Here we are.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Waiter! Waiter!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Here's your order, Pop!

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Where are my crepe suzettes?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'll have to cook them here.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: What's that book?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Fanny Farmer's Cook Book. I'm not quite sure how you mix these things.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Well, go ahead, I'm going to watch you.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Well, first you take an egg and you drop that in. Then you take two pieces of bread and butter.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You'll find out. Then add a little seasoning.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: What's that for?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You know what vitamins are for, don't you?

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Huh?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I said you know what vitamins are for?

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Well, this is ketchup. When the egg is done, you put it between the bread and there you are crepe suzette.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: That's not a crepe suzette that's an egg sandwich.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: By you it's an egg sandwich, by me it's crepe suzette.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: I won't eat it. This is an outrage. I tell you I won't eat it!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: What? After me slaving over a hot oven all day, you won't eat it? Then you can wear it.

div.stage: (Takes off toupee and slaps sandwich on bald head)

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: I'll have the law on you! Get the manager! Manager! Where's the manager?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Take it easy, Pop. I'll fix it.
All right, all right! Here you are! Here's something for you.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: Ah, I want a red one.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Never mind the red one here's the bad news.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: 76 dollars! That's exorbitant.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That's a mistake. It should be 96.

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.p: I won't pay! I won't pay it! I'll have you arrested.

div.stage: (OLD MAN adlibs. CONNIE grabs the ear phone and blows. 2 WAITERS rush on and carry the OLD MAN off)
(SALLY enters followed by OTIS and ROSIE)

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Sorry Mister, but that job you gave me I can't accept.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Why you're missing the opportunity of a life time.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I'd love to go and dance for a lot of society folk and see a real party.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: That's just what you're going to do.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: But where'll I get the clothes?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Don't worry about that. Nockerova hasn't sailed, but her trunks have.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: But how will I look in her clothes?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You'll look slicker than a sink. All you need is a little dolling-up.
sp.stage: (Takes Rosie's opera cloak and throws it over Sally)
sp.p: Here give me that cape, let me fix your hair.

Mother taught me to pluck chickens up in Squantanville and here I am dressing 'em up in New York. Look her over, Mme. Nockerova. Now let me see you walk. No, no! Mean dogs, wicked airdales. Oh not a bit like it. Watch the professor. Put 'em down easy pick 'em up light.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: What about the Russian accent?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I am Mam'selle Nockerova ze great dansair. You are a sweet young man, cherie. I could love you vaire much.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Some chaps have to use a needle to get an affect like that. You're wonderful Sally. What a riot you'll be at the Ball. I'll be your manager. Rosie will be your maid and I'll even take your dog and disguise him as a French poodle. And I guess they don't raise brains in Squantanville.

lg.l: On with the dance,
On with the dance,
Don't you know it's your one big chance!
I'll be a wonderful star,
Really how clever you are,
I'll be supreme
Is this a dream?
Ev'ry heart there I mean to entrance;
'Twill be simply divine,
And, oh, how I'll shine,
At the dance, so on with
the dance.
You'll be a wonderful star
No-one will dream who you are
You'll be supreme
This is no dream
Ev'ry heart you are bound to entrance
You'll be simply divine
And oh, how you'll shine,
At the dance, so on with the dance.
On with the dance,
On with the dance,
It's a wonderful big romance;
She'll hit 'em good and proper
Not a thing is going to stop her,
We've only had half a glance;
But we are certain Sally
Knows the way to lead a ballet;
She's bound to make some advance.
I can't deny
I mean to try
For I must make the most of my chance.

div.stage: (ENSEMBLE exit through gate, OTIS and ROSIE last leaving SALLY alone)
(Enter CONNIE from R.U.U. with broom - Rosie changes to "Silver Lining" CONNIE sweeping sees SALLY stops)

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: May I help you wash the dishes, Sally?

div.stage: (SALLY nods. CONNIE helps her wipe dishes as SALLY sings last strain of number)

(EVERYONE dancing around, SALLY clog dancing on table, as it ends they all go off waving to Sally. SALLY throws opera cloak to ROSIE and plucks the two feathers out of her hair and gives them to OTIS. THEY all exit. OTIS and ROSIE last. CONNIE presenting OTIS with bill as he goes, through door. SALLY climbs down from the table, music changes to Silver Lining. SHE takes dish pail and begins washing dishes as CONNIE after putting one table on top of another mops the floor)
