lg.l: To a celebration so remarkable as this,
Of course we're all invited;
Such an invitation we could not afford to miss,
So we are quite delighted,
Ev'rybody who is someone,
Who wants to keep in view,
Has to call here, so we're all here;
We're very glad to think we're included too,
For it's nice to know you count in the exclusive few.
Doesn't she look thin, dear?
How did he get in here?
Have you heard?
That to a Duke we're going to be presented?
Upon my word, how splendid that His Highness has consented.
They say he's a refugee
From some romantic place
Is it true? Oh tell me so!
The gossip of the case.

sp.speaker: Tenors
sp.stage: [In unison with first two lines of Girls]

lg.l: He---hit---some place.
Left without the slightest trace.

sp.speaker: Basses
sp.stage: [In unison with last two lines of Girls]

lg.l: He led them a merry chase
They're not--- since seen his face.
Yes, he's really a duke,
But it's disclosed,
Not long ago
He had the fate to be deposed.
Oh what a shame
Who was to blame?
Well such a fame,
Checkergovinia -- that's the name.
For in that foreign state he made history,
He is some potentate, full of mystery,
Checkergovinia - Checkergovinia.
If a leader you'd be reckoned
You must never lose a second
As a hostess you must follow what is new!
Every day you'll keep your eye on
Any likely social lion,
Find a fresh attraction ev'ry month or two.
If you want to play the social game,
If you really want to make your name,
The only thing to do,
Is to show them something new;
In Society variety's the key to notoriety,
A duke will bring you lots of fame,
He's a picture in a golden frame,
And we all agree a title,
Is particularly vital
If you want to play the social game.

div.stage: (During opening enter RICHARD FARQUAR with MRS. TEN BROCK. DANCE. Opening over. Exit SIX GIRLS and JIM R.1.E.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: I think these costumes are perfetly charming.

sp.speaker: Mr. Farquar
sp.p: Yes, aren't they? I asked all my guests to wear their Checkergovinia costumes in honor of the Grand Duke.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: I say, the most marvelous girl in the world has just driven up to the house. If she looks as good in the close-up as she did in the flash I got of her, the rest of the girls may as well give up the game. Who is it? Won't you tell me?

sp.speaker: Flunkeys
sp.p: Mr. Otis Hooper.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: That's all right. I know the way. I'm over twenty-one.
sp.stage: (At the same time OTIS appears at the head of the steps)
sp.p: Good evening everybody - My what a wonderful party - I hope I'm not too late for the food. Ladies is there a Mr. Farquar here?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: I am Mr. Farquar.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Howdy stranger. Of course you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Mr. Farquar
sp.p: No, sir, I do not.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You don't - what would my mother say. I am Mr. Otis Hooper, personal manager of Madame Nockerova.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Yes, yes, of course.... I hope nothing has happened.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: No, she's here. But we almost didn't get her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Really - ?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Yes, we had quite a time getting her past the imigration- board.
She's mislaid her address book and couldn't remember her last husband's name.

sp.speaker: Flunkeys
sp.p: Madame Nockerova.

div.stage: (SALLY appears at the top of the stairway. She is gorgeously gowned in a French crestion with a small hat, a tall-handled parasol, open-work stockings, golden brown orchids, etc. On one side of her is ROSIE, on the other is SASCHA with his violin in a case and carrying a music roll. ROSIE carries Custard, ornamented with a large bow of ribbon)

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh, what a lovely garden! Elle est charmante!

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Good evening, Madame.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Bon noir, Bon noir. Bon noir.
sp.stage: (SALLY comes down C. winks at Otis as she goes down)
sp.p: Rosie, please take my babe and give him what you call the air.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Ow, Madame.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: What's a matter? You hurt?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Why should I be hurt?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You said "Ow".....

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Sure I said Ow ... O-U-I...ow...that's French for yes, ya dope!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: This place is beautiful! It reminds me of ze garden of my dear friend ze Crown Prince of Siam -- tres-tres-charmante.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Gee, that Berlitz guy is a marvel! Mme, I want you to shake hands with Mr. Farquar.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: How do you do, how do you do? How do you do?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Je suis enchante de faire votre consissance, Mademoiselle. Soyez a votre aise-- on me dit que vous eten une tres grande artiste.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I'm sunk!

div.stage: (OTIS grips Sally. THEY register extreme consternation)

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Say oui!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oui -

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Oh yes, oui, oui!

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Allow me to present Mrs. Ten Brock.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Wh...what name did you say?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Mrs. Ten Brock.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: How do you do?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: How do you do?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: She is a lady who devotes much of her time to settlement work.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Settlement work?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Pardon me, Mr. Farquar - you see the Mme. doesn't understand English very well. Settlement work, she's -- a bill collector.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: That's all right, let it go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Mrs. Nockerova, your face looks very familiar.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.stage: (Turning half away from her. Afraid of being recognized)**
sp.p: Really...?
You 'ave perhaps seen me perform in Europe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: No - - - But I've surely seen you before - - -

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Her pictures were in all the papers, at the time the great Russian writer Sordoff fought a duel about her with the -- the Vice President of Switzerland.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: How dreadful!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Were either of them killed!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I don't remember!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Don't remember!

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Does she say she doesn't remember!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Not at all -- merely a case of resemblance and you know --

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Zey shot each other but were zey both killed, Otees?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well kid -- Madame, I don't quite recall, but it took one of them, quite a while to heal up. I don't think it did them any good.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: But, why bothair? Zere are so many men. And what good is a Vice-president anyway?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Oh Lady, burn my clothes. She says the cutest things... You know Mrs. Tea Spot - no - well - all right - let it go!

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Madame Nockerova, I hope you're going to spend some time with us.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: No, I am soree. You see I am so busy singing and washing dishes...

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Washing dishes...
What? What did she say?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh yes, I am very domestique. You would nevair guess it to look at me, eh?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: May I say I think that adds to your charm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Washing dishes.
Now I know who it is -- You remind me of -- You look very much like a little girl down at our settlement house.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Really? How -- how strange!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Not at all -- merely a case of resemblance and you know resemblance is resemblance. See how one grape fruit resembles another.
All right, let it go.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Mr. Hooper, I wonder if you won't go and see that Madame's maid is properly taken care of.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Mr. Farquar, I'll do that little thing for you, but I don't quite like to leave her alone -- She might get into mischief. -- She's --

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Don't worry. I'll look after her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: I'll go wth you, Mr. Hooper, and show you the way.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Mrs. Ten Spot, that's awfully nice of you. Jimmy, I'll see you listen. Where do they keep the wishing-well?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: The what - ?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: The bar, honeychile, the bar -

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Madame Nockerova, there's a society reporter writing up this affair for "Social Topics." I'm sure he'd like to have a brief story of your life.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Mon Dieu - Za police would suppress ze papair!

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: I can't believe it. You look as innocent as a primrose.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I am just ze opposite of primrose -- there is nozzing "prim" about me.

lg.l: You'll pardon our intrusion our confusion is sublime,
We've never seen a girl at all like you;
I must admit I'm rather unconventional,
A type that must appear as ultra new.
You're like a splendid flower not from our domestic clime,
An orchid that can thrill us with delight.
Alas I'm not a blossom so original,
An orchid bloom will not describe me quite;
You're nothing tame,
You're like a burning flame,
We know your name:
But all the same:
I'm just a wild rose,
Not a prim and mild rose,
Tame me if you can,
I'm a rose to suit any man;
Some passion flower,
This is my hour;
Who'll get me? No-one knows,
I'm such a wild, wild rose.
I'm frantic - romantic,
Excited - delighted,
It's thrilling - just killing.
I'm willing to play my part,
Shall I lose my heart?
Well who can tell?
It's a magic spell enchanting.
You're charming - alarming,
So slender - so tender,
Capricious -- delicious,
We love you; -- you're just complete,
We are at your feet,
You're such a wild wild rose.

sp.speaker: Flunkeys
sp.p: His Highness - the Duke of Checkergovinia.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Ladies, I thank you for this wonderful reception.

Ladies, for the past two weeks, I have been waiting, waiting for tonight. I had a little difficulty in getting here. My Prime Minister objected, but I overruled his objection. Tonight, somebody else is taking my orders -- I mean giving my orders -- and tonight I am going to sit at the table to dine..

div.stage: (THEY turn as if they'd come on just ahead of CONNIE who follows them on, the POOR GIRLS, hanging around him. He is in the uniform of Pzchekagovinian Army. The TWO FLUNKEYS follow. One carrying tray with liquors, the other a tray with coffee. They place these on a table and retire)

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Oh please Duke, may I sit on your right hand at dinner tonight?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'm sorry. I need my right hand to eat with. Ladies again I thank you in the name of Checkergovinia.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Your Highness, I do wish I could have some little souvenir to remember you by.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: How would you like this little scimovitch or native dagger.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Is it thsharp.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Is it thsharp? Well I should say it was. It's a nippy little thing. I'd hate to have to be followed upstairs by that - would you like it?

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You may have it.
Again I thank you in the name of Checkergovinia.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Duke, have you met Mrs. Ten Brock?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Oh yes. she's a very charming woman, don't you think so?

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Tell me, is she wealthy?

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: She has millions.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: A kindly voice -- millions!

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: But you'd have to work awfully hard to get her.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I never have to work -- hard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Good evening, your highness.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Good evening. You look charming.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Thank you, your Highness.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I was just saying to the ladies -- I'll have to work awfully hard if I don't get her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Tell me your highness can you come and dine at my house tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'm so sorry. There are a lot of people coming to dine at my place. I should lose my job if I weren't there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Lose your job?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Wh -- what I mean to say is - there would be trouble in diplomatic circles. But I have every other Thursday night off and one Sunday a month.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: I had no idea the duties of royalty were so arduous.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Oh, frightfully so. Besides, I must think of my customers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Customers?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Customs, customs! The customs of my country compels me to think of my people, and I must think of my people.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: I wonder if you will ever be restored?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Oh, don't say that.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: I adore Europe!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Really?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: I used to go over every summer.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Every summer?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Every summer!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock and Connie
sp.p: Every summer!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You've traveled extensively.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Tell me - are your stays long?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: I beg your pardon?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That's wrong. That's a faux pas.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Ah, Mrs. Ten Brock - I've been looking for you. Have you seen Mme. Nockerova?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: No, I haven't.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I beg your pardon, but what name did you say?

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Mme. Nockerova - the singer.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: You'll oblige me by not mentioning that lady's name again in my presence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: Do you know the lady?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Know her? She's the cause of all my trouble. I fell in love with her. For her I pawned the crowned jewels and bought her a pearl necklace.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: There was a sandal of course.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Scandal! In less than a week I was playing tag around the palace with the revolutionists.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: And now she's here.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Here - In Amer -i-ka? In America?

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Here in this garden.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Akra - etc. Gavolt! (Gevalt)

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: I beg your pardon?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I was speaking in my native tongue --

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: What an awful situation.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Not at all. I want to meet her. There are several little things I want to say to her.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: You say she was visiting the court at the time of the revolution?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Yes - she was in the palace the time the revolutionists broke in. It was she who nudged -- she called me at the first alarm too late -- she seized the pearl necklace and swam the Schnitze-Komiski.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ten Brock
sp.p: The What?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: The Schnitze-Komiski.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: What is that may I ask?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You may. Oh, I see - you're asking. Why that's our native river.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Oh I see. I never would have guessed it.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You've never heard of the Schnitze-Komiski?

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: I never have.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'll send you an Atlas.

lg.l: I'm a Duke from a wonderful clime
Where I've had a remarkable time.
My people are splendid but rather unique
They like revolutions at least once a week,
On Sunday you may be a King,
On Monday you won't have a thing.
On the banks of the Schnitze Komiski
They're all just as wild as can be;
Any time without reason or rhythm
You may find it is wiser to flee
In the night they may rouse and chase you.
And prod you with bay-nets like me;
If you meet with defeat
They'll cut off your retreat
Where the Schnitz flows down to the sea.
Our Sundays are dismals and blue
The same as they're wishing on you;
To ride on a train is a ten dollar fine
And you must be in bed by a quarter past nine.
We've no Sunday pictures out there
And for dancing you're sent to the chair.
On the banks of the Schnitze Komiski
You don't have to brew on the sly;
Making Hootch out of bits of potatoes,
And hair oil and wood-pulp and rye;
When we dine we can just swim in wine
So come on girls fore gather with me;
And I'll treat everyone
To a beautiful bun
Where the Schnitze Komiski
(The peaceful Komiski)
Just gurgles its way to the sea.
On the banks of the Schnitze Komiski
They're going to close everything down
Cabarets - they will nail up the doors
And they'll shut every theatre in town.
Making love they will stop very soon
No amusements at all there will be
Even children I hear
They'll import them next year
Where the Schnitze Komiski
(The peaceful Komiski)
Just gurgles its way to the sea.
On the banks of the Schnitze Komiski
Their novels will take you by storm;
When you read you must wear bathing suits
For they're really so frightfully warm.
Working girls want to turn into vamps
When they reach about page 93;
And my old grandma
Wants to grab grand papa
Where the Schnitze Komiski
(The peaceful Komiski)
Just gurgles its way to the sea.
On the banks of the Schnitze Komiski
The fellows are glad they're alive
Pretty girls - we'll just commandeer them
And sell them in bunches of five
And they dress - so to speak, more or less,
Well they're simply as bare as can be;
And the most a girl needs
Is a small string of beads
Where the Schnitze Komiski
(The peaceful Komiski)
Just gurgles its way to the sea.
On the banks of the Schnitze Komiski
There's rather a shortage of coal
By the talk, it's as bad as New York
Where they say they don't change their tune
We'll be feeling as cold as can be;
If it freezes tonight
He shall get frost-bite
Where the Schnitze Komiski
(The peaceful Komiski)
Just gurgles its way to the sea.
On the banks of the Schnitze Komiski
The houses are cheap as can be;
Working men do not stay out to lunch
From eleven o'clock until three.
When they build from suspicion of graft
They are really remarkably free;
As for all profitees
They just lop off their ears.
Where the Schnitze Komiski
(The peaceful Komiski)
Just gurgles its way to the sea.
On the banks of the Schnitze Komiski
I played the political game
I told all the usual lies
And I got all the usual blame
Till at last when I'd waddled and foddled
They got just as sick as can be
And just like poor old Cox
I was well on the rocks
Where the Schnitze Komiski
(The peaceful Komiski)
Just gurgles its way to the sea.

div.stage: (Enter SALLY R.2. goes to R. front. Enter BLAIR C.)

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: There you are. Why did you run away from me? Who are you - won't you tell me?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Why are you so anxious to know?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: You are so exactly like a poor little girl who washes dishes in a restaurant.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Really do you zeenk that I am this poor little girl who washes deeshes in a restaurant?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: No, no of course not, that is ridiculous. Your clothes - your foreign accent. --

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: This lettle friend of yours is she nice.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: She's charming - just as you are.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Merci -

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: You are just what I could want to have made of her.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh, you don't like her as she is.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Yes, I do - but of course she hasn't had the education you have - or the experience in life.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: NO? No, of course not.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: And though she looks like you she isn't nearly as pretty.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: You don't zeenk zat might be just ze clothes?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Certainly not.
Clothes mean nothing to me. If you were wearing rags you would look even more charming.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: You don't mean zat.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Yes, I do. I never believed in love at first sight before. -- But then it isn't first sight, for you're exactly like an older sister of this little girl who I was half in love with already.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Nonsense. That is not love. It's just the effect of this beautiful garden and the scent of the flowers and the --

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: No - No, it isn't - it's you.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Silly -- I wish I could live in a beautiful garden like this.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: If you really care, you and I can live in this garden - forever and ever -

lg.l: Mem'ry takes me back away
To an early childhood day
Then I stood within a little wood as the day was fading
I remember, oh so well
Strolling in the dusky dell
I would thrill because the Whip-po-will was serenading
-Trilling while stars were rapidly filling the sky.
Whip-po-will I used to love to hear you call to me
Whip-po-will I knew he meant the world and all to me
When the sun had gone to rest
I could hear you from your nest
Whip-po-will you used to whistle tenderly
And when the moon would play
Across the branches of the tree above
You would sing your plaintive little melodies of love.
For that though you're no longer near
In my dreams I always hear
Whip-po-will ever calling to me.
While the dusky night bird flew
To his evening ren-des-vous
In the dell I heard the vesper bell so softly ringing
As its music died away
And the sky began to gray
All was still and then the whip-po-will began his singing
Trilling whle the stars were rapidly filling the sky.

div.stage: (Exit. After number Whip-po-will - enter ROSIE from L.2.E. runs over toward R.1.E. OTIS enters from upstage C)

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Rosie! There you are. I've been looking all over the garden for you.
Gee! You look like swell. Now that we're all alone slip me a little kiss.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: No - I won't!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I see. You've got other plans. - All right let it go.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Oh Otis! I know we're not going to get away with this.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Rosie, come on now, be a good fellow - She's a riot I tell you - and before I'm through, they'll be naming cigars and cold cream after her.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: I know something is going to happen.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You're the worst moaner I ever saw, You are the champion two handed kill joy of the world. Why do you say something's going to happen?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Just before I met you - I heard a hoot-owl.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well let him hoot if he wants to. I should worry about an owl.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Why, Otis Hooper don't you know that means bad luck.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Bad luck! Why?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: The last time I heard one of those birds was the night my poor old Grandpa had his ribs broken in two places.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well, your Grandpa shouldn't go into such places.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Hello.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well, as I live and breathe if it isn't my old friend Jimmy Spelvin. How are you? I'm awfully glad you blew in. You're just in time. I want you to meet the wife, that is she isn't the wife as yet. She's my ball and chain to be. Rosie, I'd like very much to have you meet Mr. Spelvin, but don't laugh. Shake hands with Miss Rafferty, Mr. Spelvin - Mr. Spelvin, Miss Rafferty.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Good evening. How do you do. By the way, I've just been talking with Mrs. Ten Brock...

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Awfully nice girl --

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: ...about Mlle. Nockerova, and she says there's liable to be some fun this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Fun? Atta boy - that's what we like, plenty of fun.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: You know the guest of honor at this party is, who do you suppose. The Duke of Pzchekagovinia.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I don't know what I'm laughing at but I suppose it's all right. Jimmy, I don't wish to appear to have a lame brain but where does the laugh come in?

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Why don't you see. The Duke is the chap who gave Nockerova her famous string of pearls!

div.stage: (Laughs more heartily. Slaps Otis on the back)

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: And the prisoner ate a hearty breakfast. You - you mean to say that the Duke of Checkergovinia knows Mme. Nockerova.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Knows her? You don't suppose he sent her the pearls by rare free delivery? He was her Cher and -

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Oh, all right, let it go.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Can you imagine what will happen when they meet?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Oh yes, I am imagining it.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: I'll bet the fur will fly.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: There are a whole lot of other things that are going to fly besides fur!

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Well, good bye Miss Rafferty.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Rosie if we don't have a blow out in our rubber heels we'll be at the station in ten minutes. You scatter in several directions and search the grounds and see if you can't find Sally.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: What shall I tell her when I find her?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Tell her I'll race her to the station.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: So you're floored at last.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Rosie, don't be silly. You never saw anybody from Squantanville floored by a little thing like that.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: I knew when I heard that hoot girl.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Listen Rosie, I'm not going to let this stump me. I'll see the Duke - get his ears up like a rabbit. Make a couple of wise cracks - you leave it to me.
sp.stage: (JIM sees SALLY and BLAIR strolling at back - snaps his fingers to attract OTIS's attention)
sp.p: There's a game I love. On your knees boy.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: No, no, look - she's even got old Blair going now. I thought he was vamp proof.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Vamp proof, not with that baby. For a tiny woman, she can do an awful lot of damage. She certainly is some siren.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: The good old Lorelei has nothing on her.

lg.l: I remember reading in an old mythology of the lovely, luring Lorelei
In the olden times she was a siren of the sea, Theda Bara of the days gone by --
The silver stars were jealous of her gleaming golden hair;
She won the heart of ev'ry man who saw her beauty rare -
She set 'em off their bean; of she was pescherino. She dressed like Eve without the fig-leave Eve used to wear.-
Upon a rock she sat all day, the lovely Lorelei - No sailor who sailed her way could ever pass her by
If once he heard her calling, for her he'd soon be falling.
The lovely, luring lying Lorelei.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Brothers, a small colleciton will now be taken up.

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: Hooper, behave yourself.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I'm sorry - be broadminded - all right, let it go.

lg.l: Nowadays a restful rock is very hard to reach;
Sailormen not easy to recruit
Maidens of today can only pose upon the beach
In a snappy one-piece bathing suit.
Very good. You may step to the living room, and have one slice of pineapple.
A Navy man from Yankee land who danced her way to go.
Said, "Hello, Kiddo - as my widow you can spend my dough -
No girl I've seen can match you; don't let Flor Ziegfield Catch you.
He'll put you and your rock upon the Midnight Frolic show."
She'd jolly them and bunk 'em and when they fell, she sunk 'em The lovely, luring, lying Lorelei.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Sisters, a crap game has been suggested.
Remember my operation.

lg.l: Such a lovely Lorelei you ought to learn to be
All the Navy men for you would fall -
Any man who saw her when she went to see the sea,
Never came home to his wife at all -

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Keep it clean.

lg.l: 3. A fellow on a liner, full of tender heartedness -
cried, "Through my glass I see a girl, who's lost her bathing dress."
4. Let's go to her assistance, for judging at this distance
I really think it must be Mary Garden in distress."
With Manner bright and breezy, she proved that Gobs are easy,
With lovely, luring lying Lorelei.

div.stage: (CONNIE-DUKE enters leaning on arms of FLUNKEYS)

lg.l: Upon a rock she sat all day
So wonderful and bright
Historians refuse to say
Where the old girl sat at night
She lured men till she got 'em
Then vamped them to the bottom
This lovely, luring, lying Lorelei.

div.stage: (FLUNKEYS let him fall. They do not move)

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: There it goes!
Must you do that? It's very unbutlerish. Get me a brandy!
Did he say he would or he wouldn't?

sp.speaker: Flunkey
sp.p: There are the drinks, sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: I feel like a new man.
There's one for the new man.
I don't like that Flunkey fellow - he's very rude. He had the audacity to ask me what stable I was riding for.

div.stage: (Music, he listens, then goes into dance and finishes falling on settee L) (Jadnetely's "Preludium")

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: What are you doing here?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I'm on the track of a kid-napper! A fellow has gone and stole away my little Sally - the finest dish-washer I ever had --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Well I'm not the fellow --

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I know who the fellar is all right. It's that country-chap that ain't never stopped talkin' about himself since the minute he heard the doctor say: "It's a boy!"

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I know him. Zoupe!

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: It ain't only because of the dish-washin! Sally's a nice girl. I like her and the lady at the settlement told me to look after her.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: But why come after me?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I didn't come after you. This fellar's here too --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You mean he's here at my party?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Yes. I've traced him right to this place. And when I catch him. I'll just go up to him and say: "Look here you loafer - what do you mean acting like this?"

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: And if he hasn't a good answer I'm going to take him by the neck. A nice fellow to have around by the neck. You I'm going to say: "You're a low-down good-for-nothing kid snapper--"

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Stop it! You are liable to miss.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: And then if he gets fresh I'll give him a good kick.

div.stage: (Illustrates with knee chasing CONNIE around stage)

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: There it goes. You'll have to stop eating raw meat.
sp.stage: (Runs around in a circle, then stops. Bell rings, starts again and stops R. front)
sp.p: Who won?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Won? Won what?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Isn't this some game we're playing? My dear Shendoff - you've got the wrong idea. You should never forget that you're a Checkergovinian - you should never lose your temper, be more tactful, more diplomatic. You should approach him and say: "My dear Mr. Hooper -- "

div.stage: (At the same time place hand back of neck and with the other grab him quickly. Choke him and throw him on the floor as enter FARQUAR R.1.E.)

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: I wonder if you Highness -- why what the -- !

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Oh, pardon me. This is one of my loyal supporters. I was just greeting him according to our quaint Pzchekagovinian custom.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: He seems quite overcome by your condescension.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: How do you do?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Go in and ask one of the footmen to give you a glass of wine, my man. You would no doubt wish to drink the Duke's health.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Oh yes - I would like to make several wishes about the Duke's health!

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Right this way, if you please.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Thank you -

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I will see you tomorrow good Shendoff --

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: You bet your life you will.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Charming fellow.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: I admire your affability - you're so democratic.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Well, what's the use of putting on airs? Most of the time I treat Shendoff like an equal.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Pardon me. Oh, Mme. Nockerova.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oui - ?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Will you come here just a moment.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Certainment -- Vous la vous. Excuse moi?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: May I present you to his Highness the Duke of Pzchekagovinia.

div.stage: (BOTH bow very low - then recognize each other - start)

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: What did you say the name was?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Nockerova, the famous singer.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Oh, Madame Nockerova. Comment un vas.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Tres bien - et vous?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Bon. I believe we met before -- ?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Your face was rathair familiar.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You can bet your sweet life - I think it was at Monte Carlo that we first met.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oui.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Oui - we were both together. You kept on helping me take my money off the roulette board.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'd been doing fairly well till you began to help me.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Voila! It all comes back to me!

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Well, now that I see you're old friends --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Yes, we've been in a lot of hot water together.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Have you really, then I'll leave you to your pleasant reminiscenses. Mme. Nockerova is going to sing for us presently, Duke.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oui, I think I 'ad beetair go now an' get ready --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Wait a minute - come here!
What is the little game?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You bet your life I do. Do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: You bet your life I do.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: What are you doing here?
Never mind. How did you get here -
That's enough. Where did you get those pearls - that dress? Sally, you look beautiful, but why Nockerova? Why didn't you tell me this before?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I can't explain but you've always been so nice to me. You won't give me away will you.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Give you away? Of course I won't give you away - bless your little heart! But why Nockerova - I see. You told me you always wanted to be a singer.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: That's it.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Well, don't worry about me. I'll swear you're Ginger Rogers if you want me to.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh thank you, Connie. You're a dear sweet boy and I'll let you wipe the dishes for me tomorrow.
Connie!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Sally!

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Your Highness --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.stage: (DUKE puts on hat quickly - walks up and down in front of bench - attempts to rest foot on bench. Misses it, falls, gets up, staggers around back of bench to front of it - sits, posing - then rises)**
sp.p: You wish to see me?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Tell me, who is that lady? That just left here --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That's Mme. Nockerova.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Nockerova! I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I beg your pardon --

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'm positive.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: That Russian girl --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I ought to know she broke my heart and made me lose my throne.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: So that's Nockerova. And I am just another name on her list! Another one of her victims.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: What the h---is it all about?

div.stage: (Enter OTIS, L.2.E. OTIS slaps Duke on the back. DUKE turns and grapples with Otis. Both run up and down stage twice)

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Whoa! Hesitate - we'll get 'em in the next round.

div.stage: (Fans Duke with handkerchief, then mops his head. Kisses head)

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Oh! I'm blistered.
Don't you ever do that again.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Don't you worry. I won't.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: For that, in my country, you'd fight.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well, why don't you fight?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: This is not my country.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You misunderstand me. I don't want to quarrel with you. I don't want to race you. I want to have a chat with you.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Is this your flower pot?
My, how tall your sweet peas are.
sp.stage: (DUKE in putting on hat, tickles Otis with feathers in nose)
sp.p: Don't do that, I've got hay fever. I was wondering if by any chance you could be the Duke of Checkergovinia.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I am the Duke of Checkergovinia.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Sally also told me you were going to stand by her.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Great!
It's fine of you and it shows in spite of being a Duke you're a regular fellow. And if you ever need a friend.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Send for me. I'll tell you where to go! -- to find one.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Oh, Duke, you play me so rough.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Hello, Otis, there you are.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Hello Rosie!

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Did you find Sally?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I did, and everything is all right. She and the Duke are as friendly as Park and Wilford.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Then we have nothing to worry about.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Not a thing. I've got more good news for you. Sally's singing here tonight, and I know she's going to make a great success; and if she does, I've got a chance of getting her a contract with the Follies.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Say, if you do that you'll make some heavy commissions. An' if you do that I think I'll marry you.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You'll marry me?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Yeah!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You'll have to give me a little time to think that over.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: No I won't! I've made up our minds you're going to marry me.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I am not ...

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: What!!!!!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Er---ah---I don't like you that way---I like you but not that way.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: So what? You didn't like olives the first time you ate 'em did you?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: But you like 'em now, don't you?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Well, you'll give me the same chance you'd give an olive, won't you? Say, I got a surprise for you. Turn around.
From Otis to Rosie. Love and kisses.
Thanks, Otis.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Is that a real diamond I gave you?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: If it ain't you're out fifteen bucks.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Come on! Get it up! Expect me to buy my engagement ring. You cheapskate!!!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I guess I can afford fifteen dollars.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Now all you got to do is pay ten dollars a week for the next three years.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Do you think I'll make you happy, Rosie?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: You'd better. Oh, sure. Sure. You're lousy to look at but you're all mine. I guess I'm the only dame in the world dumb enough to fall for you...but you do something to me, ya crumb...

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Gee - you accepted me?

div.stage: (THEY go into a clinch and hold it as ENSEMBLE enter when they are all on OTIS notices them and THEY exit hurriedly)
(Enter MR. FARQUAR R.2., JIM L.2 and ENTIRE ENSEMBLE)
(Write Introduction by Farquar to Sally's big number - Song and Ballet)

lg.l: Our anxious eyes
Await this great surprise
She is not here
Will she appear?
Where is this wild rose?
She's no prim and mild rose;
Tame her if you can;
Some passion flower
This is her hour;
We are very glad we've met her;
We have loved her from the start;
She's won ev'ry heart,
We can't forget her.
Who'll get her no one knows
She's such a wild, wild rose.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Stop! Why is this girl here.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Why Blair are you crazy?

sp.speaker: Jim
sp.p: What's happened to Blair? Go on please don't stop your dance.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Mme. Nockerova ruined the life of our guest of honor -- Are you going to entertain the woman who did this?

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: But Blair please -- the Duke is here. I don't want a scene.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Either I leave this house or she does. She is cruel and heartless.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Very well I will go - I'll go at once.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: You had no consideration for my poor friend the Duke why should I show consideration for you?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Why? I'll tell you why. Because I'm not this dreadful woman. I'm not Nockerova.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Not Nockerova?

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: I don't believe you. You're just trying to escape from an unpleasant situation.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Wait a minute.
What are you saying? Why of course she's Nockerova.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Certainly she is.

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: How could you do this to me - why couldn't you for once in your life play fair? --

div.stage: (Enter DUKE and MME. TEN BROCK. Laugh)

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Here is the Duke. He recognized Mme. Nockerova at once.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I am quite intimately acquainted with her.
Yes, this is Mme. Nockerova -- those pearls she is wearing are my pearls and I should not be surprised if a closer examination did not reveal my suit of silk lingerie in which she swam away!

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Then she is Mme. N --

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Yes. Oft in fine summer evenings I have sat in my garden while she sang to me.

lg.l: On the banks of the Schnitze Komiski
My darling you wandered with me
Till the night when the big shindy started
We thought it was better to flee
You recall how - they roused us and showed us
You fled along my balcony
When I ran through the trees
In my best B.V.D.'s
Where the Schnitze flows down to the sea.

div.stage: (CHORUS repeats last two lines. Enter POPS. POPS has evidently taken the invitation to drink the Duke's health quite liberally)

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Oh, there you are. I've found you at last kid-napper!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: What are you talking about? You darn fool.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Sally.
Why Sally! I'm so glad I've found you Sally. This is Sally - my little dish-washer.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: A dish-washer -- ?

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Don't tell me I'm wrong?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Certainly you are!

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Rosie, you know Sally. Ain't this little girl our Sally?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: I should say not!

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Oh, my poor head. What is wrong?

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You're drunk.

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: I'm not drunk! And I won't be insulted by you! You're nobody -- you're just one of my waiters!

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: A waiter! Did he say a waiter, etc.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Now we know he's mad!
Take him away!

sp.speaker: Pops
sp.p: Take me away! It's true - he is a waiter! And what's more he's a rotten waiter.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: Mme. Nockerova, I'm extremely sorry for all this disturbance. Won't you continue your song?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Ensemble
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: It's no use, I'm not going to pretend any more.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: Mme. Nockerova.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: The Duke is trying to save me from being humiliated but he knows I'm not really Nockerova.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Mr. Shendoff was right. I did wash dishes in his restaurant. And now that you know this if you want me to stay, I will.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: I thank you. But I think you had better leave.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh, I see! As long as you thought I was this terrible woman you were crazy about me - but now you're not interested in me any more! I'm not good enough for you and your guests.

sp.speaker: Farquar
sp.p: This lady's car.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: That isn't necessary. Sally, I'll take you home. Ladies and Gentlemen, I have the honor to bid you good night.

div.stage: (Starts off with SALLY followed by OTIS and ROSIE)

lg.l: Who is she? No one knows
She's just a Wild, Wild Rose.

div.stage: House curtain rises, disclosing "FOLLIES" travelling stage, through chiffon draw curtains. Butterflies flying about then draw curtains open.

Enter first BUTTERFLIES, then the BAT at the end of the movement. BUTTERFLIES exit R. and K. and enter MOTHS (small girls) Ballet dance at Cue - SALLY enters C. premier dance and at picture, travelling stage goes forward out over orchestra. BOYS march down the aisles, throw wild rose bouquets on the stage. SONG "SHE'S JUST A WILD ROSE" Etc.

lg.l: She's just a wild rose
Not a prim and mild rose
Tame her if you can
She's a rose to suit any man
Some passion flower
This is her hour
Who'll get her, no one knows,
She's such a wild, wild Rose.

div.stage: (Stage goes back as chiffon curtain closes and SALLY comes through. BOYS come up on stage, shutter comes down. BOYS sing)

lg.l: Dear little girl we love you, dear little girl
Though the dress that you wear is a grand affair
You made us care
And we'll take our Sally away from the Ballet
To that wonderful valley of dreams.

div.stage: OTIS discovered changing cards on baskets of flowers. Heading 1st card basket L.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Love and kisses. Jimmy Spelvin and the boys.
Roses are red, violets blue - that poor egg ought to get twenty years.
A quaint old Irish sentiment "Kahxeltoph". Joe Ginsberg.

div.stage: (Note: he tears cards and replaces them with his own card)

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: What are you doing?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: What's all the shootin' for? - Hello Rosie. I'm just putting my card on some of these flowers.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: You've got a nerve!

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: These are from gang of fellows Sally met at the Farquar party. I didn't like them anyway.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Wasn't the ballet wonderful, Otis?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: You bet. If success was water, I'd be Niagara Falls.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: You? What did you have to do with it?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Everything. I got her this contract with the Follies, didn't I?

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: I'll make a fortune out of Sally, and I'll lay it at your feet.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: A large fortune?

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: It'll look large beside those tiny feet.
Oh, boy, that's a slicker.

sp.speaker: Rosie
sp.p: Father won't let me marry you, unless you can support me properly.

sp.speaker: Otis
sp.p: Well, I can start you on bread and milk, the same as he did.

div.stage: (Enter BOYS, carrying SALLY - place her on sofa, group around her)

sp.speaker: 1st Man
sp.p: What's the matter with Sally Green?

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: She's all right!

sp.speaker: 1st Man
sp.p: Who's all right?

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Sally! Three cheers. Hurray! Hurray! Hurray!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Boys, you're all of you wonderfully kind and I want to thank you. I only wish I was the Duke, so that I could decorate you with orders.

div.stage: (Throwing roses to BOYS who start and exit)

sp.speaker: Men
sp.stage: (As she hands them the bunch of flowers)
sp.p: Oh, thank you, Sally! You're wonderful! I'm going to press this and keep it forever, etc.
sp.stage: (THEY ALL exit as they get their flowers)
sp.p: Good luck, Sally! We're strong for you, you know that, don't you, etc?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.stage: (They are all off. She starts to look among the flowers)**
sp.p: Oh, dear -- he hasn't even come to see me. And he hasn't sent me any flowers. They all seem to be from Otis Hooper.
Ah!
Come in!
Oh!

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: You look disappointed. Were you expecting Blair?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Blair wrote me two letters asking me to forgive him - but I wrote back saying I never wanted to see him again - He has never answered my letter or been to see me. Men are so stupid.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I'm very happy tonight because you made such a wonderful success. You looked charming! I knew you could do it. Oh, see what I've brought you.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Thank you, Connie.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: They're not from me. This note goes with them.

It seems quite like my old waiting days carrying notes to ladies, I'm not waiting any more. I'm going to be married. I beg your pardon - Yes, to Mrs. Ten Brock that very tall lady. We haven't settled yet, when the ceremony is going to take place. She'll make a good wife - so easy to find in a crowd.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: He says after the way he behaved at his uncle's party he hasn't dared to speak to me - but some day when I forgive him, if I ever do - I am to send him one of these flowers.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: How does he figure you're going to keep them? After three or four days they don't smell so pretty - of course, you might press it in your album.
sp.stage: (Takes flower, (wild rose), she is holding out to him)
sp.p: Ah, you want me to take it now?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: If you can find him.
Excuse me, Connie. I must change my clothes.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I shall search most diligently. It may take a week or a month. But I'll find him. I'll now go and search.
sp.stage: (He motions to BLAIR to come to him, hands him rose)
sp.p: Sally, supposing I do find Blair. Shall I tell him you forgive him?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: No, no, don't do that. I'm going to make him ask me a lot of times before I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Connie
sp.p: I see. You don't want him to think you were just waiting for him to come around.

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: That's it exactly - and Connie!

div.stage: (CONNIE signals to Blair laying his finger on his lips and pussy-fotts out of the room. He turns at the door and grins)

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: CONNIE!
sp.stage: (Exit CONNIE. SALLY mounts on chair looking over top of screen)
sp.p: Why Blair!

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: Sally dear!

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: Oh, that's not fair!

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: But you have forgiven me?

sp.speaker: Sally
sp.p: I haven't said so. Your feeling for me is only fatherly. It's Nockerova that you really love!

sp.speaker: Blair
sp.p: It's you whatever name you're called. Will you marry me?
That's wonderful! We're going to that --

lg.l: Dear little, dear little church round the corner
We'll slip there one day on the sly;
We don't want a fuss, nothing gaudy for us
We have quite settled that, you and I.
She's a girl so it's no use to warn her.
He's a boy and so he doesn't care.
In our hearts we shall sing,
And the joy-bells shall ring
At the church round the corner
It's just round the corner
The corner of Madison Square.

div.stage: (Shutter closes - curtains follow. Six flower girls enter from R. and L. strewing wild roses about stage, when last two exit take away shutter - showing "church around the corner." As curtains open, lights come up slowly, groups discovered, others enter - first six bridesmaids (green dresses) then four little girls (bridesmais - pink dresses) then JIM and FARQUAR then OTIS and ROSIE, DUKE and MRS. TEN BROCK - and last SALLY and BLAIR - two pink bridesmaids carrying train)
